Edward Glaeser is an advocate of building more highrise housing in New York City as a way to reduce the city's housing shortage and lower housing prices. There's something to this--increasing the supply of housing in New York would no doubt be helpful. But, apart from any issues of impact on neighborhoods (and subways), Glaeser's idea has an important flaw.
Highrises are expensive to build. The taller they are the more expensive they are on a per square foot basis. So when a highrise is added to the city's housing stock, it's not the same as adding, say, a 6 story apartment building, where each unit is cheaper. That highrise can only be economically justified by the developer if he can sell it for more than its cost--if he can't he simply won't build it.
Another problem is "filtration." Economists assume that if you build new housing, older units will filter down to poorer people, eventually to the true poor. But that only works if new entrants don't come in and grab up the units. In New York and other highly desirable cities they will. Corporations will use the unit for occasional housing. Suburbanites who've wanted to move back to the city will do so. Well and good, but it doesn't create any new housing for existing New Yorkers. In San Francisco, some new downtown highrises only have a minority of permanent residents.
I'm all for more housing supply in cities, but creating affordable housing is not as simple as an economist's two line graph.

reporting abuse to children and elderly, is in fact, the law. citizens are obliged to report any abuse toward vulnerable people. it can always be done anonymously.  another important question is why so many of us do not report.

Actually, not all states have "obligation to report" laws.  For example, Pennsylvania did not have such a law.  Teaches, counselors, and administrators were not forced by law to report abuse of any kind.  I was a teacher in CA and we were obligated to report abuse.  And it could NOT be done anonymously. And if abuse was found and we had not reported it, we would be in a lot of trouble.  We were taught the signs of abuse in those pesky "in-service" days that taxpayers hate.  But over the years, we have learned about abuse and need to keep up.  All states should adopt laws about reporting abuse.  This case alone should spur that movement.

How can we ever hope to correct anything, any system or institution -- school, church, sports, politics or the Wall Street -- unless some of in the know report the wrong to the proper authorities, and on time?

Otherwise, we are destined to be 'surprised' much later with a much worse situation.

Abusers need to face the law soon.

The fact remains indisputable that the euphoric Arab youth uprising was as much aimed at liberation from political tyranny as from hunger and humiliation. But equally it's true that, as time is passing by, it seems to be losing much of its earlier fervour and steam, not due to any intrinsic flaw or the fragility of the idea expressed through the Arab spring, or whose time had not yet arrived but, because of a strange interplay of the entrenched powerful domestic and international / regional political forces, and the remnants of the old order being the prime hurdles in materialising the spirit of Arab democratic upsurge. All this to put in perspective the "Think Unlimited" educational initiative in Jordan, backed by the Jordanisn queen Rania and executed by former Peace corps American volunteer Shaylyn Romney Garrett. Would it be wrong if one assumes that such social development initiatives by the royalty or at the instance of any such authoritarian rule could serve the purpose of enlightening the Arab minds, or seem just a clever strategy to prolong authoritarianism? For, however short lived the impact of Arab Spring might be, but, at least, it reflected the bottom-up change impulse, could it be equated with the "Think Unlimited" mind enlightening laser beam transmitted from the palace- heights of the Jordanian royalty?

Deadline—I admire you greatly as a fellow editor and commenter, but you're never going to winkle sports out of crossword puzzles, so there's really nothing to gain from continuing to characterize them as stains on our cultural matrix. Sports are almost as old as war in the so-called civilized world and are a far more admirable exercise in human accomplishment. True, sports in today's society have a lot of schmutz stuck to them, but that's mainly a product of greed—a fault that affects many other, more important, facets of modern life. That sports definitely don't interest you is fine; I feel the same way about astronomy, mythology, much modern art, and atonal music. But I don't see them as unjustified intrusions when I do XWPs. I try to figure them out any way I can and then move on. We all have subjects we're ignorant of and are happy to remain that way. When they (inevitably) pop up in XWPs, it's not a crime against humanity. Just sayin'.

To PY - Good question! Is abuse of boys by men considered sicker or more abnormal?

At least in the Catholic Church, I would think not. We were taught as girls that we were the source of temptation and sin: that if we showed the wrong inch of thigh or cleavage, a boy "would be on fire - mortal sin!!" That's a direct quote from a priest.
Our role model, the Virgin Mary, was portrayed as hairless, sexless and silent, up on a pedestal, untouchable (even by her lawful husband).

What I think occurred is that, one, the priesthood attracted men who were afraid of or repelled by women as a result of this teaching. Two, their superiors' attitude was that sex between men and boys didn't really count: that only what went on between men and women was truly sinful. This would tend to explain a lot of the forgetting and falling between cracks.

There have been reports of priests who molested young girls. But one might assume that a priest attracted to women would simply have a consenting girlfriend. The misuse of power, trust or spiritual bonds involved would not rise to the level of crime.

Going out on a limb, a bit, but that's my theory.

Maureen:
Thank you for once again using your column to arouse the conscience of a nation.
While I’m so glad this case has focused the nation on this terrible situation in which our innocent and easily intimidated children are used for the gratification of adults, I find it interesting that many male commentators admit to being horrified by this testimony because young males are involved.
Yet, we usually excuse the actions of predators toward young females as that of grown men being “led on” by their victims, confusing who is the real victim.
Yesterday, a reporter for the Sandusky trial suggested that his defense will likely suggest that Mr. Sandusky is really also a victim of a strange psychological syndrome (which sounds suspiciously like a fancy way of describing an addiction to egotism) and which will be introduced during the defense portion of this case.
If society gets an education about the horror of kids caught in such a trap, if parents are alerted to pay attention to their children, not to simply dump them into programs without continually staying in touch with their youngsters, maybe some good will come from this horror.
When I was growing up, such subjects were taboo; not so much, anymore.
Maybe that’s a good thing.
We need to understand the results of this social deterioration.
It’s up to us to put a stop to it, no matter where it surfaces.
It’s not enough to leave it up to the courts after the fact.

Any wish that I might have of visiting Alabama as a tourist has been totally squashed. I would not put myself in a position of being arrested because I wasn't a native Alabamian. I am sure that countless others will take the same view.

The whole story simply reinforces the caricature of Alabamians as closed minded and set in a past that no one else would want to see reclaimed.

Now if you want to see hypocrisy just go to Alabama. Here we have a state that is primarily conservative. It is a Republican stronghold and these good supporters of capitalism engage in one of the most Socialistic practices; limiting the free movement of capital and labor. Oh the capital has gone there in the form of foreign auto manufacturers who have found cheap anti-union labor and generous tax breaks.

So we have an example of people who were low wage to start with willing to work for a bit more even if the benefits are sparse. These people will bee looking for that Social Security check in the following years, and yet will vote for someone who will take those checks away if he can.

But these same people also have created an atmosphere of hate and demonetization against those who are also willing to come and do even lower wage labor with no SS or Medicare, just to escape poverty. But if you ask these workers who have moved up if they are believers in the Capitalist system, you can give odds almost all of them will say they are.

Yet immigration laws are Socialistic, made to protect the local workers from competition by those who are willing to do those lower wage jobs. The agriculture industry is beginning to see the harm caused by this movement but are powerless against entrenched demagogues who need others in a lower social class than them to attack. The illegals have become the latest group for them to look down on.
